choices.text: There should be an absence of transmission of endemic measles
The duration of absence of transmission of measles should be 1 year
The transmission should be at a low level
A well-performing surveillance system should be present

questions.text: The criteria for elimination of measles include all except that -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement 'the transmission should be at a low level' is incorrect because measles elimination requires complete absence of endemic transmission, not just a reduction. Elimination is defined as the interruption of continuous transmission of the measles virus in a defined geographic area.

  • Eliminationmeans stopping endemic transmission, not merely reducing case numbers.
  • Absence of endemic measles transmissionmust be documented.
  • No reported casesof measles transmission should occur for at least 1 year in a defined area.
  • A well-performing surveillance systemis essential for detecting and confirming the absence of transmission.
  • This ensures that any imported case or outbreak is detected quickly and controlled effectively.

Explanation of Other Options:

There should be an absence of transmission of endemic measles (Option A): Correct; this is a primary criterion for measles elimination.

The duration of absence of transmission of measles should be 1 year (Option B): Correct; one year without transmission confirms sustained elimination.

A well-performing surveillance system should be present (Option D): Correct; essential to detect and respond to any imported or sporadic cases.

questions.text: Droplet precaution and isolation are to be done for all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is C) Localised varicella-zoster because droplet precautions are not required for localised shingles; instead, standard precautions with lesion coverage are sufficient unless the patient is immunocompromised or lesions are disseminated. Droplet precautions are primarily indicated for infections transmitted through large respiratory droplets.

  • Droplet precautionsare used for diseases spread via respiratory droplets (>5 µm), which generally travel short distances (up to 1 meter) and can deposit on mucous membranes of the mouth, nose, or eyes.
  • Measures include:
    • Placement in a single room or cohorting with patients with the same infection.
    • Use of surgical masksby healthcare workers within 1 meter of the patient.
    • Limiting patient movement and ensuring the patient wears a mask during transport.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pertussis (Option A): A respiratory infection caused by Bordetella pertussis, spread via droplets. Requires strict droplet precautions to prevent rapid household and healthcare transmission.

Diphtheria (Option B): Caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, transmitted via respiratory droplets. Droplet precautions and isolation are essential until the patient is no longer infectious.

Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option D): Caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, a common cause of atypical pneumonia. Transmitted through droplets; droplet precautions help prevent spread in close-contact settings.

questions.text: The recent pandemic occurred due to which influenza virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is H1N1 because the most recent influenza pandemic, which occurred in 2009, was caused by the H1N1 influenza A virus, also known as the swine flu virus. This strain spread globally, causing significant illness and deaths. It is characterised by the hemagglutinin type 1 (H1) and neuraminidase type 1 (N1) surface proteins.

  • Declared a pandemic by the WHO in June 2009.
  • Spread rapidly worldwide due to high transmissibility.
  • Causes both mild and severe illness, particularly in young adults and people with comorbidities.
  • Antiviral drugs such as oseltamivirand zanamivir were used for treatment and prophylaxis.

Explanation of Other Options:

H5N1 (Option B): Known as avian influenza or bird flu. Causes sporadic human infections with a high mortality rate but lacks efficient human-to-human transmission, so it has not caused a pandemic.

H5N7 (Option C): Avian influenza subtype affecting mainly birds; only rare zoonotic infections have been reported, and no pandemic has occurred.

H3N2 (Option D): Seasonal influenza A subtype that causes yearly outbreaks but has not caused recent pandemics.

choices.text: After the formation of the scab
Just before and after onset of rash
One week before onset of rash

questions.text: Given below is an image of a patient with fever and rash. When will the spread of this disease be at its maximum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation in the image is consistent with smallpox, a highly contagious viral disease caused by the variola virus. The highest risk of transmission occurs just before and after the onset of rash due to maximum viral shedding in respiratory secretions and from skin lesions.

  • Mode of transmission:Primarily via respiratory droplets during close contact; also through direct contact with lesion material.
  • Infectivity period:Highest just before and after rash onset, when viral load in secretions and lesions is maximal.
  • Contagiousness declinesonce scabs form, as viral shedding reduces significantly.

Explanation of Other Options:

After formation of scab (Option A): Infectivity is markedly reduced once scabs have formed, as virus shedding has diminished.

One week before onset of rash (Option C): This falls within the incubation period, when the virus is replicating internally but the patient is not yet contagious.

During convalescence (Option D): By this stage, recovery is underway, and the patient is no longer significantly infectious.

questions.text: The rash of chickenpox can be differentiated from that of smallpox by all the following characteristics except-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The rashes of chickenpox and smallpox differ in distribution, lesion characteristics, and progression.

  • Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, typically shows a pleomorphic rash with centripetal distribution and unilocular vesicles.
  • Smallpox, caused by the variola virus, produces a monomorphic, deep-seated, multilocular rash with centrifugal distribution.
  • 'Deep-seated' lesions are characteristic of smallpox, not chickenpox, making this the incorrect option in the context of differentiating chickenpox from smallpox.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pleomorphic:Seen in chickenpox; lesions are at different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, pustules, and crusts present together). Smallpox rash is monomorphic, and the lesions are at the same stage.
  • Centripetal:In chickenpox, the rash is more concentrated on the trunk than the extremities; smallpox rash is more on the face and extremities (centrifugal).
  • Unilocular:Chickenpox vesicles contain a single cavity ('dew-drop' appearance), whereas smallpox vesicles are multilocular.
  • Deep-seated:Seen in smallpox lesions, firm, embedded vesicles/pustules; not a chickenpox feature.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pleomorphic (Option A): True for chickenpox; lesions in various stages help differentiate it from the monomorphic rash of smallpox.

Centripetal (Option B): True for chickenpox; rash distribution is greatest on the trunk.

Unilocular (Option D): True for chickenpox; vesicles have a single cavity, unlike smallpox, which is multilocular.

choices.text: Chickenpox vaccine is a killed vaccine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chickenpox?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chickenpox (varicella) is a highly contagious infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which belongs to the herpesvirus family and is classified as human herpesvirus type 3 (HHV-3). The infection spreads through respiratory droplets and direct contact with vesicular fluid. The virus has a high secondary attack rate and confers durable immunity after one attack.

  • Causative agent:Varicella-zoster virus (HHV-3).
  • Infectivity:Starts 1-2 days before rash onset and continues until all vesicles have crusted; scabs themselves are generally non-infectious.
  • Vaccine:Live-attenuated vaccine, not killed.
  • Secondary attack rate:Very high in susceptible household contacts, about 85% (range 61%-100%).

Explanation of Other Options:

Scab is infective (Option B): Incorrect; infectivity ends once lesions have crusted and dried.

Chickenpox vaccine is a killed vaccine (Option C): Incorrect; it is a live-attenuated vaccine.

Secondary attack rate is 70% (Option D): Incorrect; it is higher, around 85% in susceptible contacts.

choices.text: A patient with CD4+ T cell levels â‰¥ 15%

questions.text: The varicella vaccine can be given to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The varicella vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine and can be given to HIV-infected individuals with CD4+ T cell counts ≥ 15%, as they have adequate immune function to mount a safe and effective response.

  • Indication in HIV-positive patients:
    • May be considered in clinically stable HIV-infected children or adults with CD4+ T cell levels ≥ 15%.
    • Helps prevent severe varicella infection in this group.
  • Contraindications:
    • Pregnancy:Contraindicated due to the theoretical risk to the fetus. Women should avoid pregnancy for at least 4 weeks after vaccination.
    • Severe allergy to neomycin or other vaccine components:Contraindicated in such cases. Mild local reactions are not a contraindication.
  • General recommendations:
    • Should not be given to severely immunocompromised individuals.
    • Spread from the vaccine virus is rare; if it occurs, lesions are few and mild.

Explanation of Other Options:

A pregnant woman (Option A): Contraindicated during pregnancy; vaccination should be deferred until after delivery.

A patient allergic to neomycin (Option B): Contraindicated in those with severe allergy to neomycin; mild allergy may not be a barrier.

All of the above (Option D): Incorrect because pregnant women and individuals with severe neomycin allergy should not receive the vaccine.

choices.text: Four days before and two days after the appearance of the rash
Two days before and two days after the disappearance of the rash
Four days before and four days after the appearance of the rash
Two days before and four days after the appearance of the rash

questions.text: A child with fever and rash presents with the findings shown in the image. What is the period of communicability of this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The period of communicability for measles extends from four days before the appearance of the rash to four days after its appearance. This time frame represents the highest risk for transmission through respiratory droplets.

  • Causative agent:Measles virus (Paramyxoviridae family, genus Morbillivirus)
  • Mode of transmission:
    • Direct contact with respiratory droplets from the nose, throat, or mouth of an infected person
    • Airborne spread via droplet nuclei
  • Portal of entry:Respiratory tract
  • Period of communicability:
    • Starts 4 days before rash onset
    • Continues up to 4 days after rash appearance
    • Corresponds to both the late prodromal stage and the early eruptive stage
  • Public health importance:
    • Understanding this period is critical for isolation measures to prevent outbreaks
    • Isolation is advised for at least 4 days after rash onset
  • Clinical correlation:
    • Rash appears after the prodromal stage (fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik's spots)
    • Communicability is maximal during this period due to high viral shedding
  • Control measures:
    • Early detection, isolation during the communicable period
    • Contact tracing and vaccination of susceptible contacts within 72 hours

Explanation of Other Options:

Four days before and two days after the appearance of rash (Option A): Incorrect; this underestimates the infectious period after rash onset.

Two days before and two days after the disappearance of rash (Option B): Incorrect; measles remains communicable before rash onset and well before its disappearance.

Two days before and four days after the appearance of the rash (Option D): Incorrect; the infectious period before rash onset is underestimated here.

choices.text: The incubation period is five days
Otitis media is a common complication

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Measles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Otitis media is a well-recognised and common complication of measles. It results from secondary bacterial infections occurring during the course of the illness, often due to the immune suppression caused by the measles virus infection.

  • Causative agent:Measles virus (family Paramyxoviridae, genus Morbillivirus)
  • Incubation period:Usually 10-14 days from exposure to onset of fever; not five days
  • Mode of transmission:Respiratory droplets and droplet nuclei
  • Complications of measles:
    • Otitis media (most common)
    • Pneumonia
    • Diarrhoea
    • Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup)
    • Encephalitis
  • Otitis media in measles:
    • Develops due to bacterial superinfection during viral illness
    • Contributes to morbidity, especially in children
  • Public health relevance:
    • Complications increase severity and risk of mortality, especially in malnourished children and immunocompromised individuals

Explanation of Other Options:

Incubation period is five days (Option A): Incorrect; incubation period is 10-14 days, not five days.

Caused by orthomyxovirus (Option C): Incorrect; measles virus belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family, not Orthomyxoviridae (which includes influenza viruses).

Large number of carriers (Option D): Incorrect; there is no chronic carrier state in measles. Transmission occurs only during the communicable period.

choices.text: From onset of rash to 3 days after rash
Two weeks before Rash to 1 week after rash
During full course of the disease
From Catarrhal stage to 7 days after rash

questions.text: What is the recommended period of isolation for measles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The recommended isolation period for measles is from the catarrhal (prodromal) stage up to 7 days after the onset of rash. This covers the period when the patient is most contagious and effectively reduces transmission risk.

  • Communicability:
    • Begins during the prodromal (catarrhal) stage, before the rash appears
    • Continues for about 4 days after rash onset
  • Catarrhal stage features:
    • Fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis
    • High viral shedding occurs in this stage
  • Rationale for isolation:
    • Measles virus spreads via respiratory droplets and droplet nuclei
    • Highest infectivity before and shortly after rash onset
  • Public health guidance:
    • Early isolation prevents exposure of susceptible contacts
    • Particularly important in healthcare and community settings

Explanation of Other Options:

From onset of rash to 3 days after rash (Option A): Incorrect; misses the early highly contagious prodromal phase.

Two weeks before rash to 1 week after rash (Option B): Incorrect; overestimates the period of infectivity.

During the full course of the disease (Option C): Incorrect; isolation is not required for the entire disease duration, only during peak infectivity.

choices.text: Measles vaccine is replaced by measles rubella vaccine
Follow up campaign refers to mass vaccination campaign organised as a periodic event
Age of children covered is 9 months-15 yrs
Mop-up campaign is a part of the strategy under the measles elimination program

questions.text: All of the following are true about the measles elimination program except -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mop-up campaigns are not part of the core measles elimination program strategy. They are reactive outbreak-control measures, conducted in specific areas where measles cases have been detected, to rapidly vaccinate susceptible individuals and interrupt transmission. In contrast, the measles elimination program focuses on high routine coverage, follow-up campaigns, and targeted measles-rubella vaccination.

Key points from the program:

  • Vaccine change:Measles-only vaccine has been replaced with the measles-rubella (MR) vaccine to provide dual protection.
  • Follow-up campaign:A periodic, mass vaccination activity aimed at children who may have missed routine doses.
  • Target age group:Typically 9 months to 15 years, covering those most at risk and ensuring population immunity.
  • Mop-up campaign role:Used in outbreak response, not in the planned elimination strategy.

Explanation of Other Options:

The measles vaccine is replaced by the measles-rubella vaccine (Option A): Correct; done to protect against both measles and rubella.

Follow-up campaign refers to a mass vaccination campaign organised as a periodic event (Option B): Correct; these are supplementary immunisation activities to maintain coverage.

Age of children covered is 9 months-15 years (Option C): Correct; ensures vaccination of both routine and missed children/adolescents.

questions.text: For the eradication of measles, what is the percentage of immunisation coverage needed, according to the WHO?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The World Health Organisation recommends achieving an immunisation coverage of at least 96% for measles eradication. This high coverage ensures minimal numbers of susceptible individuals in the community, interrupting transmission and preventing outbreaks.

Explanation of Other Options:

68 (Option A): Much lower than the required coverage; insufficient to interrupt transmission.

72 (Option B): Below the WHO-recommended target; would still allow measles spread.

84 (Option C): Higher than the previous two but still inadequate for eradication.

choices.text: Infection in early pregnancy causes milder disease
A foetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.text: Which of the following is false about rubella?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infection with rubella during early pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, is associated with severe congenital abnormalities (CRS) and not a milder form of the disease.

  • Causative agent:Rubella is caused by an RNA virus of the Togavirus family.
  • Source of infection:Human cases, both clinical and subclinical, act as the source.
  • Communicability:Less communicable than measles; infectivity is highest 1-5 days after rash onset.
  • Mode of transmission:Primarily droplet infection from the nose and throat; the virus also spreads vertically via the placenta.
  • Vertical transmission:The virus can cross the placenta and infect the foetus, causing congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Host factors:Primarily affects children aged 3-10 years; postnatally acquired rubella is usually mild, but congenital infection can have severe consequences.
  • Incubation period:2-3 weeks, average 18 days.
  • Clinical features in postnatal rubella:
    • Prodromal symptoms like sore throat, low-grade fever, and malaise.
    • Lymphadenopathy (auricular, occipital, posterior cervical) often precedes rash.
    • Rash appears first on the face, spreads rapidly, and clears in three days.
    • Complications such as arthritis/arthralgia may occur, especially in adults.
  • Importance of early pregnancy infection:Infections before 8-10 weeks of gestation may result in multiple severe malformations; later infections tend to be less severe but are still significant.
  • Public health relevance:CRS prevention is a key goal of rubella vaccination programmes.

Explanation of Other Options:

Droplet infection (Option A): True, Rubella spreads via droplets from the nose and throat of infected persons.

Vertical transmission (Option B): True, the Virus crosses the placenta, causing intrauterine infection and CRS.

Foetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness (Option D): True, Late pregnancy infection can cause isolated deafness, though the risk of major malformations is lower.

choices.text: Vaccination is done with killed virus
Period if infectivity- 4 days before and 4days after onset of rash

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the causative organism of the skin lesion shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lesion shown in the image is a blueberry muffin rash, characteristic of congenital rubella. Rubella virus belongs to the family Togaviridae.

Agent Factors:

  • Agent:Rubella virus - an RNA virus of the Togaviridae family.
  • Source of Infection:Mainly from nasopharyngeal secretions; the virus also recovered from blood, CSF, and urine.
  • Communicability:Less communicable than measles. Infectivity is greatest from 5 days before to 6 days after rash onset.
  • Vaccine:Live attenuated RA 27/3 strain is used for immunisation.

Mode of Transmission:

  • Direct person-to-person spread via respiratory droplets.
  • Vertical transmission occurs from mother to fetus, leading to congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

Host Factors:

  • Occurs mainly in children aged 3-10 years.
  • Infection in early pregnancy can cause severe fetal abnormalities.

Incubation Period:

  • Usually 2-3 weeks, average 18 days.

Clinical Features in Postnatal Rubella:

  • Often mild or subclinical.
  • Rash appears on the face, then spreads to the trunk and extremities.
  • Lymphadenopathy, especially postauricular and occipital nodes.

Explanation of Other Options:

Causes measles (Option A): Incorrect, Measles is caused by a virus of the Paramyxoviridae family, not Togaviridae.

Vaccination is done with killed virus (Option C): Incorrect, Rubella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, not killed.

Period of infectivity - 4 days before and 4 days after onset of rash (Option D): Incorrect, for rubella, infectivity extends from 5 days before to 6 days after rash onset.

questions.text: The triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes all except -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Forchheimer spots are not part of the triad of congenital rubella syndrome. They are small, red spots on the soft palate and uvula, seen in the acute phase of rubella infection, particularly in older children and adults. The classical triad of CRS consists of sensorineural hearing loss, congenital cataract, and congenital heart disease.

Congenital Rubella Syndrome:

  • Causative Agent:Rubella virus, an RNA virus of the Togaviridae family.
  • Transmission:Vertical transmission from infected mother to fetus, especially during early pregnancy.
  • Pathogenesis:The Virus crosses the placenta and interferes with organogenesis, particularly during the first 8-10 weeks of gestation.
  • Classical Triad:
    1. Sensorineural hearing loss- due to damage to the auditory nerve or inner ear structures.
    2. Congenital cataract- lens opacification present at birth.
    3. Congenital heart disease- commonly patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary artery stenosis, or ventricular septal defect.
  • Other Possible Manifestations:Microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura ('blueberry muffin' rash), developmental delay.
  • Prevention:Immunisation with live attenuated RA 27/3 rubella vaccine before pregnancy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sensorineural hearing loss (Option A): True, a key component of the CRS triad.

Congenital cataract (Option B): True, a major ocular manifestation of CRS.

Congenital heart disease (Option D): True, structural cardiac defects are common in CRS.

questions.text: The reduction in cases of diphtheria in recent surveillance reports is due to -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

High coverage of vaccination against diphtheria has been the primary factor in the significant reduction of cases reported in surveillance data. The diphtheria toxoid is given as part of the DPT or pentavalent vaccine in routine immunisation schedules. This widespread immunisation, especially in children, leads to herd immunity, interrupting transmission and preventing outbreaks.

  • Mode of protection:The Diphtheria vaccine induces immunity by producing specific neutralising antibodies against the toxin.
  • Routine immunisation:Administered as part of DPT/pentavalent combination vaccines.
  • Impact:Marked decrease in diphtheria cases globally and nationally in areas with high vaccination coverage.
  • Herd immunity:Widespread vaccination reduces the number of susceptible individuals, limiting spread even to the unvaccinated.
  • WHO recommendation:Only adjuvanted DPT vaccines should be used in immunisation programs to enhance potency.
  • Indian data:Declining trend in reported cases linked to improved coverage under the Universal Immunisation Programme (UIP).

Explanation of Other Options:

Chemoprophylaxis (Option A): Useful for preventing spread among close contacts using antibiotics, but not the main factor in large-scale case reduction.

Improved standard of living (Option B): Better hygiene and living conditions help control infections, but are insufficient to prevent diphtheria without vaccination.

Health education (Option D): Raises awareness about prevention, but alone cannot achieve the scale of case reduction seen with vaccination.

choices.text: Most of the infections are subclinical
Secondary attack rate is 90% in unimmunized individuals
Cerebellar ataxia may be a common chronic complication

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pertussis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is C, as unimmunized individuals exposed to pertussis have a very high chance, around 90%, of acquiring the infection upon contact with a case. This reflects the extremely contagious nature of the disease.

Pertussis:

  • Causative Agent:Bordetella pertussis is the primary cause; parapertussis may account for a small proportion of cases.
  • Source of Infection:Exclusively humans; cases (including mild and unrecognised) are the main source.
  • Secondary Attack Rate:Around 90% in susceptible, unimmunized contacts.
  • Mode of Transmission:Spread mainly through droplets during close contact; infectivity is highest in the catarrhal stage.
  • Incubation Period:Typically 7-14 days; may extend up to 3 weeks.
  • Clinical Course:
    • Catarrhal Stage:Mild URTI symptoms for ~10 days.
    • Paroxysmal Stage:Bursts of rapid cough followed by a characteristic 'whoop'; may cause vomiting, cyanosis, or apnea.
    • Convalescent Stage:Gradual recovery over 1-2 weeks.
  • Complications:More common in infants - pneumonia, bronchopneumonia, subconjunctival haemorrhages, encephalopathy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Most of the infections are subclinical (Option A): This is incorrect, as pertussis usually presents with noticeable symptoms, especially the characteristic cough.

Most infectious during the incubation period (Option B): This is incorrect; peak infectivity occurs during the catarrhal stage after symptom onset.

Cerebellar ataxia may be a common chronic complication (Option D): This is incorrect; although neurological complications can occur, cerebellar ataxia is rare and not a common chronic sequela.

questions.text: According to IMNCI, pneumonia is classified by -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pneumonia in children under five years is classified in IMNCI based primarily on the presence of fast breathing, as it is a simple and reliable sign of lower respiratory tract infection in resource-limited settings. It reflects respiratory distress due to lung inflammation or infection, even in the absence of advanced diagnostic tools.

IMNCI Classification:

  • Definition of Fast Breathing (by age group):
    • < 2 months: ≥ 60 breaths/min
    • 2-12 months: ≥ 50 breaths/min
    • 1-5 years: ≥ 40 breaths/min
  • Reason for Use in IMNCI:
    • Easily detectable sign
    • Strongly correlated with pneumonia in children
    • Minimizes the need for laboratory or radiological diagnosis in rural and peripheral health setups
  • Other Symptoms in Pneumonia (supportive, not diagnostic in IMNCI):
    • Cough
    • Fever
    • Difficulty breathing

Explanation of Other Options:

Fever (Option A): Fever may occur in pneumonia but is non-specific, as it is present in many infectious diseases. IMNCI does not use it as the primary classification sign.

Wheezing (Option B): Wheezing is more commonly associated with bronchiolitis or asthma. It can occur in pneumonia but is not a consistent feature, hence not a classification criterion.

Cough (Option C): Cough is a common symptom of many respiratory infections, including pneumonia, but lacks specificity and is therefore not used for classification in IMNCI.

questions.text: According to IMNCI, a 6-month-old child is said to have pneumonia if the child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, pneumonia in children is classified by the presence of fast breathing, with the threshold varying by age. For a 6-month-old child (2-12 months), fast breathing is defined as a respiratory rate >50 breaths/min. This age-specific threshold helps in the early detection and management of pneumonia in peripheral and resource-limited settings.

  • Reason for age-specific thresholds:Younger children have naturally higher respiratory rates, hence the cut-off decreases with age.
  • Clinical relevance:Fast breathing is a simple, low-cost, and reliable sign for pneumonia diagnosis without requiring laboratory or radiological support.

Explanation of Other Options:

40 (Option A): This threshold applies to children aged 12 months to 5 years, not to a 6-month-old infant.

60 (Option B): This is the cut-off for children less than 2 months old, not for infants between 2-12 months.

30 (Option D): This rate is well below the threshold for any age group under 5 years in IMNCI and would miss cases of pneumonia.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are signs of severe pneumonia
i. Convulsions
ii. Lethargic or unconscious
iii. Fever
iv. Not able to drink
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Severe pneumonia is diagnosed when there are general danger signs indicating serious systemic involvement and significant respiratory compromise.

  • Convulsions:Hypoxemia due to severe pneumonia can cause neurological manifestations such as convulsions.
  • Lethargic or unconscious:This reflects central nervous system depression from hypoxemia and is a critical danger sign.
  • Not able to drink:Children with severe pneumonia may have difficulty feeding or drinking due to respiratory distress and inability to coordinate swallowing.
  • Fever:Although common in pneumonia, fever is not a defining sign of severe pneumonia and can be present in mild cases.

According to IMNCI guidelines, signs of severe pneumonia include convulsions, lethargy or unconsciousness, inability to drink or breastfeed, persistent vomiting, stridor in a calm child, and severe malnutrition. Fever alone is not considered a specific sign of severe pneumonia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Only i (Option A): Incorrect; convulsions alone are not sufficient for diagnosing severe pneumonia.

i and ii (Option B): Incorrect; omission of 'not able to drink' misses a key danger sign.

i, ii, iii, iv (Option C): Incorrect; includes fever, which is not a specific criterion for severe pneumonia in IMNCI.

choices.text: Give IV antibiotics and send to higher center
Oral antibiotics, warn about danger signs and send home
No need of treatment, only home remedies

questions.text: A one and a half year old child is brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, cough, and cold. On examination, the respiratory rate is 46/minute and there are no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A respiratory rate of 46/min in a 1½-year-old child is above the IMNCI cut-off for fast breathing (>40/min for children aged 12 months-5 years) but without chest indrawing, danger signs, or hypoxia, this is classified as pneumonia (not severe pneumonia). IMNCI recommends treatment with oral antibiotics on an outpatient basis with advice to caregivers on danger signs and follow-up.

Key points from IMNCI guidelines for pneumonia classification and management in this age group:

  • Age-specific cut-offs for fast breathing (IMNCI):
    • <2 months: ≥60/min
    • 2-12 months: ≥50/min
    • 12 months-5 years: ≥40/min
  • Classification in this case:
    • Findings:Fever, cough, cold, fast breathing (46/min), no chest indrawing, no danger signs → Pneumonia
    • Severity:Not severe → managed at home with oral antibiotics
  • Recommended management for pneumonia (12 months-5 years):
    • Oral antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin) for 5 days
    • Supportive care: paracetamol for fever, adequate fluids, continued feeding
    • Caregiver education: explain danger signs (worsening breathlessness, inability to drink, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargy, chest indrawing)
    • Advise follow-up in 2 days or earlier if danger signs develop
  • Advantages of community-based oral antibiotic use (as per revised recommendations):
    • Early treatment reduces progression to severe pneumonia
    • Reduces need for hospitalization and injection-borne disease risk
    • Improves access to treatment at peripheral health facilities

Explanation of Other Options:

Give IV antibiotics and observe (Option A): Indicated only for severe pneumonia with chest indrawing or danger signs; unnecessary for mild cases.

Give IV antibiotics and send to higher center (Option B): Reserved for very severe pneumonia; not required in this child without danger signs.

No need of treatment, only home remedies (Option D): Risky, as pneumonia needs antibiotic therapy to prevent complications; home remedies alone are insufficient.

questions.text: Increased and sustained transmission of Swine Flu (H1N1) in the general population denotes which of the following stages of a pandemic?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pandemic period is characterized by ongoing and widespread community transmission of a novel influenza virus across multiple countries or regions. This stage involves significant illness burden, high transmissibility, and potential for severe disease outcomes. Public health interventions during this phase may include travel restrictions, social distancing, targeted vaccination, and heightened surveillance.

Explanation of Other Options:

Inter-pandemic period (Option A): Refers to the phase between pandemics, with no sustained novel virus transmission in the general population.

Pandemic alert period (Option B): Indicates early detection of a novel virus with limited human-to-human spread, prompting enhanced monitoring and readiness.

Post-pandemic period (Option D): Follows the peak of pandemic activity, marked by a decline in transmission and focus on recovery and preparedness.

questions.text: Drug of choice for H1N1 influenza treatment is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oseltamivir is the drug of choice for treatment of pandemic influenza A (H1N1) as it is a neuraminidase inhibitor with proven efficacy, oral administration, and a strong safety profile.

  • Mechanism:Inhibits neuraminidase enzyme, preventing release of new viral particles from infected cells.
  • Indication:Recommended for patients with severe or progressive illness, and for those with uncomplicated illness but at high risk of complications.
  • Administration:Oral; dosage depends on age and body weight.
  • Advantages over Zanamivir:Easier administration (oral vs inhaled), suitable for a wider range of patients.

Explanation of Other Options:

Zanamivir (Option A): Neuraminidase inhibitor; effective in influenza but less commonly used as it is inhalational and contraindicated in some respiratory diseases.

Acyclovir (Option C): Antiviral for herpes viruses; ineffective against influenza viruses.

Interferon (Option D): Immunomodulatory protein; not the first-line drug for influenza, limited direct antiviral effect against H1N1.

questions.text: Chemoprophylaxis of H1N1 is done using:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oseltamivir is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of pandemic influenza A (H1N1). It is recommended for individuals with close contact exposure to confirmed cases to prevent infection.

  • Mechanism:Neuraminidase inhibitor - blocks release of viral particles from infected cells.
  • Indication:Post-exposure prophylaxis for suspected, probable, or confirmed cases of pandemic influenza A (H1N1).
  • Dosage:Given once daily for 10 days after last exposure; dose varies by body weight.
  • Special points:Effective against both influenza A & B; preferred due to oral route and good tolerability.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rotanavir (Option A): Used for rotavirus infection; no role in influenza chemoprophylaxis.

Ceftriaxone (Option B): Broad-spectrum antibiotic for bacterial infections; ineffective against viruses.

Acyclovir (Option D): Antiviral for herpes group viruses; no activity against influenza viruses.

questions.text: Subclinical infection occurs in all of the following except -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Measles almost always presents as a clinically apparent illness with a typical prodrome and rash, making subclinical infection extremely rare.

  • Hepatitis A (Option A):Can have asymptomatic/subclinical cases, especially in children.
  • Diphtheria (Option B):Asymptomatic carriers can exist and transmit infection without symptoms.
  • Japanese encephalitis (Option D):Many infections are asymptomatic or mild, with only a small proportion developing encephalitis.
  • Measles (Option C):Highly infectious viral disease with almost universal symptomatic presentation; characterized by fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and rash; absence of symptoms is rare.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of direct transmission of communicable diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Droplet nuclei transmission is an airborne mode of spread, not direct transmission, because infectious particles remain suspended in air for prolonged periods and can travel long distances before being inhaled by a susceptible host.

Explanation of Other Options:

Vertical transmission (Option A): Direct transmission from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding; seen in infections like HIV, syphilis, and cytomegalovirus.

Contact with soil (Option B): Direct mode of transmission for infections caused by soil-dwelling pathogens, e.g., Clostridium tetani (tetanus) and hookworm.

Droplet transmission (Option D): Direct spread via large respiratory droplets (>5 μm) reaching mucous membranes of a susceptible person, as in influenza and pertussis.

questions.text: All are helpful in COVID-19 disinfection except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Use of mask is a preventive measure that helps reduce the transmission of respiratory droplets containing SARS-CoV-2 but is not a method of disinfection. Disinfection refers to the process of destroying pathogenic microorganisms on inanimate objects and surfaces; hence, use of mask does not qualify as a disinfection method.

Explanation of Other Options:

70% ethanol (Option A): A widely used chemical disinfectant effective against enveloped viruses like SARS-CoV-2 by disrupting their lipid membrane.

1% Glutaraldehyde (Option B): A high-level chemical disinfectant used for sterilizing medical instruments and surfaces; effective against a broad range of pathogens including SARS-CoV-2.

Hand washing (Option C): A critical infection control practice that physically removes microorganisms, including viruses, from the skin surface; though not a chemical disinfection method, it is part of standard hygiene measures for controlling COVID-19 spread.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to a Primary Health Centre with fever and breathlessness. On examination, respiratory rate is 46/min and chest indrawing is present. What is the most appropriate management protocol?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A respiratory rate of 46/min in a 2-year-old, along with chest indrawing, is classified as pneumonia with chest indrawing. As per revised WHO recommendations, these children require oral amoxicillin as first-line therapy. Hence, antibiotic initiation is the appropriate management at this stage.

Management of Pneumonia in Children (2 months - 5 years)

  • Classification:
    • Fast breathing without chest indrawing: Pneumonia - treat with oral amoxicillin.
    • Chest indrawing present: Pneumonia with chest indrawing - treat with oral amoxicillin (first-line).
    • General danger signs/severe pneumonia: Requires injectable antibiotics and referral.
  • Treatment protocol for pneumonia with chest indrawing:
    • First-line: Oral amoxicillin 40 mg/kg/dose twice daily for 5 days.
    • In high HIV prevalence areas, cotrimoxazole prophylaxis may be considered.
    • Referral only if general danger signs are present.
  • Rationale for oral antibiotics in chest indrawing pneumonia:
    • Effective against common bacterial causes.
    • Allows home-based treatment after initial evaluation in PHC.
    • Reduces hospitalization burden.

Key Points from Revised Guidelines:

  • Oral amoxicillinpreferred over cotrimoxazole for pneumonia.
  • Classification simplified into pneumonia and severe pneumonia.
  • Antibiotics must be started promptly to prevent progression to severe disease.
  • Referral is indicated only in severe pneumonia with danger signs (e.g., inability to drink, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargy/unconsciousness).

Explanation of Other Options:

Home management (Option A): Not appropriate as the presence of chest indrawing indicates pneumonia requiring antibiotic therapy; home care without antibiotics risks disease progression.

Immediate referral (Option C): Indicated only if general danger signs are present; in this case, the child has pneumonia with chest indrawing but no danger signs, so oral antibiotics at PHC are preferred.

Antibiotic and immediate referral (Option D): Combining both is necessary only in severe pneumonia with general danger signs; here, immediate referral is not required since the case can be managed with antibiotics at PHC.

questions.text: A TB patient is found resistant to isoniazid, rifampicin, kanamycin, and quinolones. He is categorised as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's resistance pattern meets the criteria for Extensively Drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB), which is defined as resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin (MDR-TB) plus resistance to any fluoroquinolone and at least one of the three second-line injectable drugs (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Classification based on drug resistance (as per WHO/NTCP):

  • Monoresistance:Resistance to one first-line anti-TB drug only.
  • Polyresistance:Resistance to more than one first-line anti-TB drug (other than both isoniazid and rifampicin).
  • Multidrug resistance (MDR-TB):Resistance to at least both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively drug resistance (XDR-TB):Resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin (MDR-TB) plus any fluoroquinolone and at least one second-line injectable drug.
  • Rifampicin resistance:Resistance to rifampicin with or without resistance to other anti-TB drugs.

Key Point:

  • The patient here is resistant to isoniazid, rifampicin (MDR-TB criteria met), plus quinolones (fluoroquinolones) and kanamycin (second-line injectable) → XDR-TB.

Explanation of Other Options:

Mono drug-resistant TB (Option A): Resistance to only one first-line anti-TB drug; does not fit as patient has resistance to multiple drugs.

MDR-TB (Option B): Resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin; patient has additional resistance to fluoroquinolone and second-line injectable, so this exceeds MDR definition.

Extremely drug-resistant TB (Option D): Not an officially recognized WHO category; the correct term for advanced resistance beyond MDR-TB is 'Extensively Drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB)'.

questions.text: Which virus causes antigen shift?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Antigenic shift is a major change in the influenza virus surface antigens (hemagglutinin - HA and/or neuraminidase - NA) that results in the emergence of a new influenza A virus subtype. This occurs when two different influenza A viruses infect the same host cell and exchange genetic material, producing a virus with novel antigenic properties capable of causing pandemics.

  • Occurs only in influenza A virusesdue to their ability to infect multiple species and undergo genetic reassortment.
  • Triggers: Recombination between human and animal influenza viruses (e.g., avian/swine).
  • Impact: Population has little to no immunity → large-scale outbreaks/pandemics.
  • Example: H1N1 pandemic (2009) from reassortment of avian, swine, and human influenza strains.

Explanation of Other Options:

B (Option B): Represents Ebola virus; causes viral hemorrhagic fever, no antigenic shift.

C (Option C): Represents Rabies virus; causes rabies, does not undergo antigenic shift.

D (Option D): Represents HIV/HTLV; retroviruses, undergo antigenic variation but not antigenic shift.

questions.text: A child presented to the clinic with history of cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and fever. There is fever and rash which arises behind the ears and is spreading all over the chest, back, and abdomen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation is characteristic of measles, a highly contagious disease caused by an RNA paramyxovirus. The illness begins with fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the '3 Cs'), followed by the appearance of Koplik's spots inside the mouth, and then a rash that starts behind the ears and spreads downwards over the body.

  • Causative agent:RNA paramyxovirus, single serotype.
  • Transmission:Primarily via droplet infection and droplet nuclei, occasionally through direct contact.
  • Prodromal stage:Fever, coryza, cough, conjunctivitis; Koplik's spots appear 1-2 days before rash.
  • Rash:Dusky-red, maculopapular, starting behind the ears, spreading to the face, trunk, and extremities in 2-3 days.
  • Communicable period:From 4 days before to 4 days after rash onset.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rubella (Option B): Caused by a togavirus; milder illness with shorter fever duration; rash starts on the face and spreads downwards; lacks prominent cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis.

Dengue (Option C): Caused by a flavivirus transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes; presents with high fever, headache, myalgia, arthralgia, and sometimes rash, but rash pattern and associated symptoms differ from measles.

Chickenpox (Option D): Caused by varicella-zoster virus; rash is vesicular ('dew drop on a rose petal'), starts on the trunk/face, lesions appear in crops, unlike the confluent rash of measles.
